subject: RE: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Question, How to get the U sound in "Up"?
msgSnippet: Hi Steve, Thanks for your additional clarification. . . and the chart. I am so very impressed with Quickscript that I am quite willing to accept it as is. It
messageBody:
Hi Steve,

 

Thanks for your additional clarification. . . and the chart.

 

I am so very impressed with Quickscript that I am quite willing to accept it as is. It is practically completely phonetic, very compact, without diacrits, quick to go on paper, and, I think, attractive. Read really did a fine job!

 

I know you are very knowledgeable about phonetic alphabets and spelling issues. Even so I was wondering if you had read Read’s manual on Quickscript yet?

 

I liked your comments and site because I am interested (and I think many new to Quickscript and other phonetic alphabets might also be interested)  in knowing which English sounds some users might find difficult to distinguish. When I started to learn Quickscript I had assumed that I would easily be able to distinguish all of the sounds. Bad assumption.

 

Your website

 

http://www.unifon.org/saunds-eng.html

 

helped some.

 

Even so, like Paige Gabhart, I cannot distinguish the much discussed vowel sounds in up and the first vowel in ago, which Read apparently accepts as the same sounds or near enough that they get the same symbol. Nor, can I distinguish the vowel sound in ox from the vowel sound in alms. It would please me if I could, but otherwise I’m perfectly willing to spell the words as Read or a consensus suggests. I’m happy with either the assumption that others can hear the difference in sound or speak with a slightly different accent than I do. I’m equally happy with the assumption that the sounds are close enough that it doesn’t matter so use the same symbol. Even so, I suppose to really resolve this would require some sort of study about how many speak the sounds one way or another. Or do you have a good answer?

 

I’m hoping that Quickscript might become more popular . . . perhaps starting out as a kind of shorthand? In this case, I think it’s important to let potential users know where Quickscript (or even the IPA) might show pronunciation differences even tho the user might not hear them. This would save them so of the effort I’ve put into distinguishing sounds I cannot distinguish. It’s also good to let newbies know where there is some controversy; but with Paige’s and HeyMister57’s caution that the controversy is interesting but probably not worth too much discussion.

 

By the by, I can get your site to produce sounds and use its links to get to fortunecity/van gogh contrary to the experience of HeyMister57. However, the site was a bit inconsistent in whether it would produce some of the sounds on the first try. So HeyMister’s suggestion about improvements are probably worth considering.

 

It’s been a while since I’ve looked at Spanglish. I hope to look again soon.

 

Good Wishes,

 

 

e-mail: ed.gaddy@...

phone:  301 390 5115

 

-----Original Message-----
From: stbett [mailto:sbett@...]
Sent: Saturday, May 25, 2002 12:31 AM
To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Question, How to get the U sound in "Up"?

 

Ed and others,

For some reason, this message did not post to the site.
It did post to saundspel, so you can check it there.

http://groups.yahoo.com/group/saundspel/message/9725

--- In Read_Alphabet@y..., "Ed Gaddy" <ed.gaddy@e...> wrote:
